articles.headline: Ford Seeks to Eliminate $10.4 Billion of Its Debt
articles.snippet: Ford’s action resembles what General Motors and Chrysler are required to do as conditions of their government loans.
articles.abstract: Ford’s action resembles what General Motors and Chrysler are required to do as conditions of their government loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  The Ford Motor Company said on Wednesday that it hoped to eliminate as much as $10.4 billion in debt by giving cash and stock to debt holders as part of a revamping of its balance sheet.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: It Rings, It Shoots, It Stumbles
articles.snippet: T-Mobile is introducing the Samsung Memoir, the first 8-megapixel phone camera in the United States. Photos are excellent, but there’s a lot of mediocrity.
articles.abstract: T-Mobile is introducing the Samsung Memoir, the first 8-megapixel phone camera in the United States. Photos are excellent, but there’s a lot of mediocrity.
articles.lead_paragraph: I’ll never forget the time I visited a Riverwalk restaurant in San Antonio and ordered risotto: rice that’s been stirred in broth until it’s rich, creamy and perfect.

articles.headline: 50 Years After Revolt, Clampdown on Tibetans
articles.snippet: Chinese authorities have imposed unofficial martial law in areas where ethnic Tibetans live.
articles.abstract: Chinese authorities have imposed unofficial martial law in areas where ethnic Tibetans live.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAQU, China — Enraged nomads stormed through this windswept town on the Tibetan plateau a year ago this month, raiding a police compound, setting fire to squad cars and forcing police officers to flee. To the north, Tibetans on horseback galloped into a schoolyard, ripped down a Chinese flag and hoisted a Tibetan one, shouting “Free Tibet!”

articles.headline: For Young President, Flecks of Gray
articles.snippet: For a guy who prides himself on a stress-free demeanor, the changes above President Obama’s temples may be speckled evidence of the strains of the job.
articles.abstract: For a guy who prides himself on a stress-free demeanor, the changes above President Obama’s temples may be speckled evidence of the strains of the job.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Well, that didn’t take long. Just 44 days into the job, and President Obama is going gray.

articles.headline: Another Karzai Forges Afghan Business Empire
articles.snippet: Mahmoud Karzai’s swift rise has stirred suspicion among Afghans, who resent his brother’s seeming tolerance for unsavory activities.
articles.abstract: Mahmoud Karzai’s swift rise has stirred suspicion among Afghans, who resent his brother’s seeming tolerance for unsavory activities.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  Eight years ago, Mahmoud Karzai was running a handful of modest restaurants in San Francisco, Boston and Baltimore. Today, Mr. Karzai, an immigrant waiter-turned-restaurant owner, is one of Afghanistan’s most prosperous businessmen.

articles.headline: Abruptly, Expatriate Bankers Are Cut Loose
articles.snippet: The salaries and bonuses were great, the lifestyle grand. The party’s over, and expats are joining the ranks of the jobless.
articles.abstract: The salaries and bonuses were great, the lifestyle grand. The party’s over, and expats are joining the ranks of the jobless.
articles.lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE  Losing your job anywhere is disorienting, but imagine being laid off when you work in a foreign country. Not only is your source of income, and perhaps a good part of your identity, suddenly yanked away, but often you lose your right to remain in the country.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Julia Werdigier

articles.headline: Piecemeal Recovery Fills Void in a Former G.M. Town
articles.snippet: An Indiana town dotted with vacated G.M. plants is rebuilding itself with a patchwork of small businesses.
articles.abstract: An Indiana town dotted with vacated G.M. plants is rebuilding itself with a patchwork of small businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANDERSON, Ind.  This city, about 50 miles northeast of Indianapolis, has long been saddled with dubious distinctions.

articles.headline: Drug Ruling Puts Devices in Spotlight
articles.snippet: Medical device makers remain insulated from the kind of lawsuits allowed by the Supreme Court’s ruling. But, perhaps, not for long.
articles.abstract: Medical device makers remain insulated from the kind of lawsuits allowed by the Supreme Court’s ruling. But, perhaps, not for long.
articles.lead_paragraph: An injured consumer can sue a drug maker  but not a medical device maker?
articles.byline: By Barry Meier and Natasha Singer

articles.headline: U.S. Sets Big Incentives to Head Off Foreclosures
articles.snippet: The Obama administration began an ambitious effort to help troubled homeowners, offering lenders and borrowers big incentives.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration began an ambitious effort to help troubled homeowners, offering lenders and borrowers big incentives.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Wednesday began the most ambitious effort since the 1930s to help troubled homeowners, offering lenders and borrowers big incentives and subsidies to try to stem the wave of foreclosures.

articles.headline: 14 Trading Firms Settle Charges for $69 Million
articles.snippet: More than a dozen Wall Street trading firms systematically cheated their customers of millions of dollars by improperly slicing bits of profit from countless trades, federal regulators said on Wednesday.
articles.abstract: More than a dozen Wall Street trading firms systematically cheated their customers of millions of dollars by improperly slicing bits of profit from countless trades, federal regulators said on Wednesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than a dozen Wall Street trading firms systematically cheated their customers of millions of dollars by improperly slicing bits of profit from countless trades, federal regulators said on Wednesday.

articles.headline: Auditors Raise Doubts About G.M.’s Viability
articles.snippet: As G.M. reported that its survival was in doubt, the White House said that helping the auto industry was a priority.
articles.abstract: As G.M. reported that its survival was in doubt, the White House said that helping the auto industry was a priority.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  Auditors for General Motors, in one of the bleakest assessments yet of the automaker’s prospects, said on Thursday that G.M.’s survival was in “substantial doubt” even if it received all $30 billion it hoped to borrow from the federal government.
